Steady climb up. Low traffic. Love the falls at the end.

Great hike. Steep the whole way- not very many points that it levels out to give you a break. Actually closer to 2.5 miles as others have said to get all the way up and back to the waterfall. The last mile or so just gets steeper, but it's worth it for the view and falls. Will go again for sure.

This hike was wonderful! While there is a steady incline I am surprised that this was labeled as "difficult". 

Will do again!

Nice trail, we hiked packing in our two kids up to the lookouts before the falls. It has nice coverage so it's not too terribly hot. It is definitely steep, I probably wouldn't classify it as difficult if you stop before you reach the falls though. We took our 11 week old puppy and he was still running when we got down.
This was a good hike with the family. Don't be shy with your water supply

The hike is about 4 to 5 miles . Depends if you go all the way to the top. I would rate this more like a difficult hike and not very kid friendly because of how steep it is. The outcome it is wonderful and we made it to the top where the waterfall starts I would do it again but maybe in like a month or two not something I would do weekly.

First off, this hike is over 4 miles round trip. Enjoyed this hike, very steady incline the entire way. Gets steeper the higher you go and there are some challenging spots especially if you go up above the falls to the pools. Coming down can be hard on the knees ( I have very bad knees) and I felt it. We went on a Saturday and there were a lot of people on the trail, fortunately the trail is pretty wide in a lot of places. Fun to cross over some of the streams. Good hike.
Great hike all uphill. Beautiful falls. We went late spring. My wife and I are avid hikers and runners we made the trip in 1 hr and 50 min.
Okay hike but great ending. You will have to cross a creek either on a log or get your feet wet.
Awesome!  My favorite hike.  It's more like 2.5 miles to the falls.

This hike was awesome. Pretty rough at times and it's extremely easy to lose the trail once you get to the waterfall. This hike was definitely not 1.3 miles. It was 3.4 one way. Pretty steep inclines, walking through quite a bit of streams and water.
So fun!! Pretty wet still, but so worth it!

I've done the hike three times now. I really enjoy it. It's not the most scenic hike up because it's mostly covered but the trees and a couple of the meadows are beautiful. I've actually slipped into the falls also which was a little scary just because it was cold and night time, but it was shallow enough for me to climb out quickly. I would recommend this hike, although if you take someone that doesn't like hiking they will complain about the incline.
Gorgeous!  Moderate uphill but the best is hearing the thunderous creek as you hike, best sound ever.  Love nature.  Shaded and fresh spring smells.

I’d heard a lot about Horsetail Falls from a coworker of mine. Beautiful views, pretty easy hike. I attempted to get my fiance' to join me long ago, but after reading the reviews on AllTrails, she got scared off by the mediocre hikers complaining of a steep trail and scary drops. (not a thing, by the way. There are hikes that are way steeper than this in the area, though I will concede that this hike is relentless). 

Finally, a friend that is home from Southern Utah for the summer said he’d be down for the hike and we headed toward the hills. 

The trailhead begins on the bench of Alpine, a city in Northern Utah County. We arrived to a parking lot full of Mormon haulers and I suspected correctly when I deducted that because of the day of the week (Wednesday), that there were youth groups from the local LDS congregation making the sojourn. 

The beginning of the hike is a nice incline that doesn't let up for most of the duration albeit a small flat section that meanders through a meadow.  The trail is rocky, and I remember thinking that for as wide as the trail was, it could sure use a grading job. But, I don’t mind that it was in it’s rougher form either, because I really don’t like trails that follow roads and I felt that the amount of natural obstruction allowed for the hike to be more adventurous. I just wouldn't wear flip-flops on the hike, that's for sure. 

The hike up was spent exchanging pleasantries with my friend that I hadn't seen in a long time and the conversation slowly got deeper as we plunged deeper into the forest, leaving the valley and its noise behind. We talked mission stories and lessons learned, and made silent goals for the future as we allowed the healing powers that exist in nature to purge our minds of the filth of the week and restore anew. 

Reaching a lookout where you could see the falls, the more adventurous side of me screamed that I must push further to reach the top of the falls. So, on we went crossing small streams that plunged down small waterfalls and miniscule riverbeds down out of the mouth of the small canyon we were rimming. The trail kept going, but the light got more and more diminished. Having not traversed the trail before, we decided it best to play on the side of caution and move back toward the valley once more, descending the rocky trail for our descent to the ever faithful Camry for a trip to a local Frozen Yogurt eatery.
It is a longer hike.  close to 6 miles out and back from Dry Creek Trailhead.   the waterfall is magnificent and the views are amazing once u reach the top.   i highly recommend it.

The falls are incredible, this hike should be on everyone's list. It's a steady climb the whole way but not insanely steep it's just that there are really no breaks to the climb. I know everyone is all over the place in the mileage but I clocked it at almost exactly 6 miles round trip to the base of the falls. The trail was well marked except we had to veer off and fallow the ribbons to get to the base of the falls which I would highly recommend. There was no snow on the trail at this time but it is a little muddy still.

This is one of my favorite hikes! It's fairly steep so that makes it a harder hike, I wouldn't say it's a hard on the difficulty but it's a bit tougher than a medium hike.  the app is wrong though, hike is closer to 4.2 miles round.  it's very easy to find the falls, there is a very clear trail the entire way up!  they say dog on a leash but every time I have ever been, I've never seen even one dog on a leash which I like. definitely a great hike to go on!
Snow covered the last third of the trail. Fairly steep climb. Hike is definitely longer then 1.3 miles. Closer to 4 miles round trip.
Made it to the meadow. Did not make it to the falls. Had a fun time. It is pretty steep on the way up.
Amazing! However why it says 1.3 miles...I dunno. It's 6.4 miles round trip. Beautiful though, and worth the hike!
Awesome trail!
Loved it

This is one of my favorite hikes in Utah County. The trail is consistently steep, but easy to follow. It isn't an easy hike, physically, but not overly strenuous either. My husband and I were able to carry on a conversation throughout most of it. There is quite a bit of shade, and you go through areas of forest as well as a gorgeous meadow. There are sections of the trail that are loose rock that require you to pay a little extra attention to footing, especially going downhill. There are also several small stream crossings. You will be able to hear the falls for the majority of your hike, but won't actually see them until the end. When you get to the granite, go back to the trail. Once you get to a fork in the trail (I believe there is a sign there, but don't recall exactly what it says) stay to the LEFT. Then look for the first game trail on your left. There are usually ribbons tied to the trees to mark the spot. The game trail is steep and requires careful footing, but it will take you right to the base of the falls. When the falls came in to view for the first time I was just speechless. They are breathtaking. The rocks are slippery and some areas are steep, so please be careful!

Went with my beagle early one morning started around 8 and finished around noon. Jump on line and look up the trail, it will tell you how to get closer to the falls without falling (or rolling) down the mountain. Once you get to the granite over look go back to the real trail until you hit the fork in the road then go left and jump on the first game trail you see, it'll take you over to the falls. 

We were able to touch the water fall, but it's really slippery so please be careful and don't go alone. There is even a memorial down by the waterfall of an unfortunate fall victim. 

If your doggies like to roll in horse poop, be prepared to wash them down. Cause there is a lot of it. 

Will definitely do it again.

This hike was challenging for our family with 2 teens. Hiking up a rocky very steep creek bed, and had to make several stops to adjust to elevation changes. Had to watch every step and not much shade along the trail. We were disappointed to see how far away the falls were, as we expected to see them close enough to enjoy. All in all, not our favorite but did make for a good workout!
Steep and shifty under foot. Great waterfall with an amazing view that is second to none for a shorter hike.

Great for a shaded trail and relaxing by the falls at the end. The trail is mostly a dry creek bed so lots of navigating over river rock...and horse poo. Seriously...why isn't there some method for managing this. Anyway, there is a beautiful overlook not to be missed (just a bit up past the meadow).  Back on the main trail, I missed the final turn to the falls--watch for the trail markers and then some scrambling down to the falls. There are orange ties on bushes to help you in and back out. Overall a beautiful hike.
Uhmmmm if this was easy what is a difficult hike like?!?  So many rocks and really steep.
Beautiful falls, but the trail to get to the base is not clearly marked and is a steep scramble.
It was a steady up hill hike.

this hike was over 5 miles from beginning to end.  it was extremely rocky and steep.  creek crossing is necessary.  the waterfall is difficult to find, as the trails are poorly marked.  was told by fellow hikers that the trail used to be better maintained.  right now the trail is really bad.  i don't recommend this hike unless you are in fantastic shape.
Great day hike, beautiful meadow, go on a weekday to avoid crowds.

The hike is about 4 or so miles,it's not hard but the trail is very rocky and muddy especially if done before June. I enjoyed the view of the mountains and more so the water fall. It took us around 3 hours but I think it could take less time depending on one's pace.

Took my 6 year old on his first "backpacking" trip on this hike. We hiked to the meadow set up camp, then headed up to the waterfall the next morning. Great beginner hike, plenty of shade, lots of easily accessible water to filter (especially near the meadow). Plenty of shade throughout the entire hike. 

The only downside is that the trail is very busy, especially on the weekend. We went up Thursday and came back Friday and only saw a few people on Thursday and saw a lot more groups on Friday. Fun hike!
Beautifully magnificent
This was an awesome hike! Did this with my best friend and it took us about 3 and a half hours to go out and back but it was an amazing hike!
Thought this would be a good trail to run.  Only on the way down it is steep and you feel the elevation for sure.  Great hike and great waterfall.
Great adventure! Lots of uphill and lots of rocks! Great sights and plenty of wildlife along the trail. My wife and I are planning our return visit to do an overnighter up there!

While I've been up to the falls in past hikes, today I hiked up to the meadow.  The trail is dry for the most part and had sparse patches of snow by the meadow, but overall in great condition for this time of year.  It's  a fairly rugged trail most of the way to the falls and moderately steep in parts.  Lots of tree cover through pines as you near the meadow.  The falls are spectacular too.  One of my favorite hikes in the alpine/highland area.

This trail is awesome. It is steep in some parts and seems a little long but so worth it. The waterfall itself is beautiful. 
Hike Rate: Medium- Hard 
Length: 1-2:30 hrs
Trail traffic: none

This is a gorgeous hike however there is construction at the beginning which makes it hard to figure out which way to go. The turn off to the falls isn't marked so I went up past the falls. Meet 2 girls who took the other path at the beginning which ran the other side of river. We finally found the spectacular falls approx 4 miles round trip. Lots of horse poop on the trail :)

This hike was pretty heavy I am in ok shape and I struggled but when you finally get to the waterfall about 1-1.5 hours it is absolutely unbelievable and you will not regret making your way to the waterfall! A moose or elk scared me away the first time but ran into nothing the second time around. Is a pretty high elevation gain fast!
It's a great little hike! Lots of fun great thing to do on a Saturday morning with your family or group of friends! The falls are beautiful. Go! You won't regret it.
Nice on a summer evening... Good canopy for most of the trip. Spotted a few deer and a decent sized snake.

Wide trail (lots of water in it in early spring), with very rocky and technical stepping in places. Fairly steep at times, but I wouldn't call it relentlessly uphill by any means. The falls are absolutely spectacular, and worth every step it took to arrive there. Be sure to look for a steep trail (down) about 1.9 miles up that looks like water runoff or a game path, that's the one that takes you to the bottom of the falls, the main trail will take you to the top. Do both! This hike has awesome views of Alpine, as well as Lone, Big Horn and Box Elder Peaks!
Good hike... Rocky trail... Path to the falls is not well marked.
